text: And now, I'd like to imp- to- to present today's speakers. Victoria Woo Ph.D is a lecturer at Stanford University,
and an entrepreneur with more than 25 years of experience in startups, international management and academia.
Victoria has devoted the past decade to bridging academia and business by co-designing custom executive programs at INSEAD and Harvard,
where she helped Fortune 500 clients curate learning journeys for C-suite leaders and high-potential .
In these roles, Victoria has also facilitated dialogue and cooperation among worldwide business partners, alumni, and clients.
Since returning from a decade working in Asia, Victoria has served as a mentor for Blackbox.vc,
a non-profit organization serving the global entrepreneurial ecosystem and as an advisor for early-stage startups.
Victoria is now working on a sixth startup, which is focused on increasing engagement in the sense of community among hourly workers.
Joining Victoria today is Lynda Smith, a lecturer in Global Entrepreneurial Marketing at Stanford University and
a marketing and sales executive with more than 25 years of experience. Lynda has spent the last 15 years in high-technology products and services as the SVP of
marketing or CMO for a number of companies including Genesys Telecommunication Laboratories,
Nuance, Genpact and Jive Software. In these roles, Ly- Lynda has successfully laid
virtually every marketing function including product marketing, product management, corporate marketing, field marketing,
regeneration, channel marketing, marketing research and strategy development, all driving marketing in the US, Europe,
India, China and other major markets. Lynda has an undergraduate degree in liberal arts from Simpson College,
and an MBA from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania. Her current area of interest is what is happening in this next generation of marketing,
where digital media and social networks are combining to reshape the art and science of marketing.

it's defined by this orientation. And if you've ever been in an entrepreneurial organization

there is this whole idea of, it's about moving fast, you don't have time to stand still.
It's about being agile, being able to pivot and constantly change what you're doing from a marketing perspective,
it's about leveraging the passion that the organization has because that's so much of what people buy in the early days,
and it's also about being creative, which I'll touch on in a moment. Now, if you're someone already in a formal organization,
and you want to be a part of innovation, what we oftentimes call intrapreneurial, all of that applies as well,
even though the organization may be older, maybe more mature, whenever you're bringing that new idea,
that new concept to market, it goes back to all the principles of being in that entrepreneurial environment,
moving fast, being agile, the list we just covered. It's also focused on establishing a company in an industry or a product in a segment,
and it's about growing rapidly. So, all of those things change the way you fundamentally think about marketing.
Because marketing very traditionally has more of a planning horizon to it. We get comfortable with longer windows of being able to define campaigns,
of being able to put things out into the market. You can't do it when you're in this entrepreneurial mode.

You can switch to the next slide. Typically, people start investing in marketing when the product is ready

and you want people to really start coming to you and wanting to learn more. You hire for marketing when revenue is now a or the key objective,

well, it's either more money or it's more users um of a platform? But it's when you need to really now generate start generating mass.
And it's also when that current staff you have just can't cover the marketing effort. What I found in some wonderful new start-up says,
it just happens to be that the founder had a little bit of marketing or someone they hired have done marketing before, and that they're actually in the earliest days able to handle it.
But now there'll be a point where oh, wow. Yeah, maybe someone has really done this done this before, let's start looking at bringing him in the staff.
Next question, if you could switch over. Um. Then it comes in then to, who do I hire?
And this is just my point of view but it's worked for me. Generalists are golden. In those earliest days when you're hiring for
marketing finding someone that has pretty broad experience, not just focused on one area can be super helpful.
I also find that the marketing model drives it, um we'll talk a little bit about the marketing model in a moment but sales driven revenue,
well then you want someone who knows lead generation, sales enablement. If it's marketing driven revenue,
then you want somebody who knows brand and campaign orientation. If it's about a platform play,
you want someone who typically knows developers and if it's about growth hacking that's the model you're
following and marketing then you want someone who is uber smart on the online and digital side of things.
Hire someone who can get from A to Z with a little help, you don't have time to train these folks. Also find somebody who doesn't need an army reporting to them,
because we're talking lean moving fast, and then if you have a technically steep product, find someone who's technically steep as a marketer.
And then the last question, which is what level do I hire in at? Culture matters, avoid title creep,
too early and then you enable it, don't enable your best early starters to be a part of the company.
Experienced level doesn't necessarily mean title, um, and then finally churn will happen, some people are just better in a beginning company.

because you're moving people through what we call this hierarchy of effects, taking people from being totally unaware of
a product all the way through to where there's an action, whether that's purchased or sign up or whatever the right conversion is.
And there are layers to building that natural understanding, getting them to that purchase point.
They have to be aware, then you'd have to feed them with enough knowledge that they they understand who you are,
what you stand for, and you can get to that point where they actually like you, and then have a preference over the competition and
then finally we get the conviction that they want to engage with you and there are marketing tactics that we use at each stage of this.

And what we're doing with this marketing process is strengthening that signals so we can get into that short-term memory and if we as marketers have done our job really well,
we get all the way into that long-term memory where the real value comes because then you've got word of mouth. Someone comes up and says, "Hey,

There are different types of marketing, uh, um, and these are kind of that- the- the old traditional words for it if you will.
There's the idea of B2B marketing, and this is really about catering to businesses. Here your target audience is the business,
as well as the buyer that is internal to that company. So, if you're selling an enterprise software product,
your chances are you want to get to the person who actually uses it, but probably also there's a CIO that's involved,
there's a CFO involved, um, that you have to include. So, multiple audiences that you're catering to inside.
Then you have the world of B2C, and this is really about catering to consumers, we all are the recipient of that target audience, the consumer.
One we care a lot about now, a lot of startups, uh, a lot of intrapreneurial efforts going after this idea of B2B2C.
Here you're catering to the businesses that cater to consumers. Oftentimes, you also have to cater to the consumer so you get both the push and the pull,
and your target audience then tends to be the business, the buyer, as an individual again in the consumer.
And then, the last one, you're seeing a lot more activity around in terms of types of marketing, is this idea of B2D,
which is about catering to developers. Here you're really focusing on that individual developer to get them excited about what you're doing.
And there are different ways that you approach marketing in each of these types, and so we'll be going through that as well.
